prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SGP quasars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Four setups to observe the dust continuum and CO (6-5) line from five targets.
SGP2_25 redshift=1.868 observing CO(6-5) at 241.0994GHz in the 1st window, and the other three windows for continuum.
SGP4_39 redshift=1.716 but set z=1.868 to use the same setup as SGP2_25 and observe the CO (6-5) line at 254.59244GHz in the 3rd window.
SGP2_11 redshift=1.976 observing CO(6-5) at 232.34982GHz in the 1st window, and the other three windows for continuum.
SGP3_39 redshift=1.964 CO(6-5) at 233.29051GHz in the 1st window, and the other three windows for continuum.
SGP2_36 redshift=1.756 giving a fake redshift of 1.910238596 to make sure all four windows lie within the frequency range of Band 6, and observing the CO(6-5) at 250.89734GHz in the 3rd window; the other three windows for continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Sample.
Our sample (Table 1) contains 10 quasars at z~2 with deep high-resolution HST near-IR imaging based on the observations of Ridgway et al. (2001) and Kukula et al. (2001). They are the only available HST observations of quasar host galaxies at z>1 in the rest-frame optical which is sensitive to the stellar mass of the galaxies. We divide the 10 targets into two Science goals. This science goal contains the five objects in SGP region (Ridgway et al. 2001).
2. Correlator setup and configuration.
We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with three of them observing the dust continuum and the other one covering the CO (6-5) frequencies. This will also allow us to constrain the molecular gas emission properties from objects that have strong star forming activity in the quasar host galaxies. The redshifts of the objects are measured with the quasar MgII and C IV line emission with typical uncertainties of Delta_z ~ 0.007 (Vanden Berk et al. 2001, 600 km/s in velocity, 500 MHz in frequency at z=2.5), which is well covered with the 1.875 GHz bandwidth. This is a detection project and we will use the compact configuration of C34-1.
We adjust the frequency setups to minimize the tunings (reducing overheads) and cover the CO (6-5) line frequencies for all the z<2 sources in the first or third baseband. For the source SGP4-39, we give a fake redshift of z=1.868 in the source table to use the tuning of SGP2-25 and observe the CO line in the 3rd baseband. We also use a fake redshift of z=1.9102 for SGP2-36 to make sure the four basebands are falling into the Band 6 frequency range and observe the line in the 3rd baseband.
3. Time and sensitivity requirements.
We estimate the dust continuum flux densities at the observing frequency for the sample based on the L_FIR vs.L_bol relationships of local quasar samples with comparable quasar luminosities (Figure 1). According to the luminosity correlation of the local IR luminous galaxies (Wang et al. 2011; Hao et al. 2005), we expect strong millimeter continuum flux densities of 0.3 to 0.5 mJy for the objects that have massive star formation in the host galaxies, We also estimate the intensities of the CO (6-5) line emission, adopting the CO-to-optical luminosity correlation and CO excitation ladder, found with local and high redshift CO-detected quasars (Maiolino et al. 2007; Walter et al. 2011). The peak line flux densities are 2.0 - 4.7 mJy for the CO (6-5) line. Thus, we request continuum sensitivity of 0.05 mJy per beam (in a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows) and line sensitivity of about 0.4 mJy per beam per 100 km/s channel. For the objects with strong star forming activity in the quasar host galaxies, this will allow us to detect the dust continuum at >5-sigma and detect the CO(6-5) line emission at >5-sigma in each of three to five consecutive 100 km/s channels. Based on the sensitivity calculator, the total observing time for this science goal is 2.64 hours, including the overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: MZZ quasars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Two setups to observe the dust continuum for five targets and CO (6-5) line from three of them
MZZ_1558 redshift=1.829 observing CO(6-5) at 244.42314GHz in the 1st window, and the other three windows for continuum. MZZ_9744 redshift=2.735, but set z=1.829 to use the same setup as MZZ_1558, and just observe the continuum. MZZ_9592 redshift=2.710, but set z=1.829 to use the same setup as MZZ_1558, and just observe the continuum.
MZZ_4935 redshift=1.876 observing CO(6-5) at 240.42875GHz in the 1st window, and the other three windows for continuum. MZZ_11408 redshift=1.735 but set z=1.876 to use the same setup as MZZ_4935 and observe the CO (6-5) line at 252.82379GHz in the 3rd window.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Sample.
Our sample (Table 1) contains 10 quasars at z~2 with deep high-resolution HST near-IR imaging based on the observations of Ridgway et al. (2001) and Kukula et al. (2001). They are the only available HST observations of quasar host galaxies at z>1 in the rest-frame optical which is sensitive to the stellar mass of the galaxies. We divide the 10 targets into two Science goals. This science goal contains the five objects in MZZ subsample (Kukula et al. 2001) .
2. Correlator setup and configuration.
We will tune the four spectral windows in 2.0 GHz bandwidth (usable bandwidth of 1.875 GHz), 128-channel dual polarization, TDM mode, with three of them observing the dust continuum and the other one covering the CO (6-5) frequencies, except the two highest redshift sources for which CO (6-5) is out of reach. This will also allow us to constrain the molecular gas emission properties from objects that have strong star forming activity in the quasar host galaxies. The redshifts of the objects are measured with the quasar MgII and C IV line emission with typical uncertainties of Delta_z ~ 0.007 (Vanden Berk et al. 2001, 600 km/s in velocity, 500 MHz in frequency at z=2.5), which is well covered with the 1.875 GHz bandwidth. This is a detection project and we will use the compact configuration of C34-1.
We adjust the frequency setups to minimize the tunings (reducing overheads) and cover the CO (6-5) line frequencies for all the z<2 sources in the first or third baseband. For MZZ-11408, we use the redshift and tuning of MZZ-4935 and observe CO in the 3rd window. For MZZ-9744 and MZZ-9592 (z~2.7), we give a fake redshift of z=1.829 to use the same setup of as for MZZ-1558, observing only the continuum.
3. Time and sensitivity requirements.
We estimate the dust continuum flux densities at the observing frequency for the sample based on the L_FIR vs.L_bol relationships of local quasar samples with comparable quasar luminosities (Figure 1). According to the luminosity correlation of the local IR luminous galaxies (Wang et al. 2011; Hao et al. 2005), we will expect strong millimeter continuum flux densities of 0.3 to 0.5 mJy for the objects that have massive star formation in the host galaxies, We also estimate the intensities of the CO (6-5) line emission, adopting the CO-to-optical luminosity correlation, CO and excitation ladder, found with local and high redshift CO-detected quasars (Maiolino et al. 2007; Walter et al. 2011). The peak line flux densities are 2.0 - 4.7 mJy for the CO (6-5) line. Thus, we request continuum sensitivity of 0.05 mJy per beam (in a total bandwidth of 5.6GHz with the three continuum windows) and line sensitivity of 0.4 mJy per beam per 100 km/s channel. For the objects with strong star forming activity in the quasar host galaxies, this will allow us to detect the dust continuum at >5-sigma and detect the CO(6-5) line emission at >5-sigma in each of three to five consecutive 100 km/s channels. Based on the sensitivity calculator, the total observing time for this science goal is 1.81 hours, including the overheads.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Feedback from black hole (BH) growth in the quasar phase plays a crucial role in massive galaxy evolution. We propose to obtain ALMA band 6 continuum and CO (6-5) observations of a sample of 10 quasars at z~2 with existing high-resolution HST imaging. This unique sample will allow the first simultaneous study of BH growth in high-redshift quasars together with stellar population, molecular gas and star formation in their host galaxies: ALMA observations is the only way to directly probe the total star formation rate, gas mass and gas kinematics, while HST imaging and ground-based spectroscopy measure the host galaxy luminosity and stellar mass, as well as mass and accretion rate of the central BH. We will study whether quasar host galaxies follow the same star formation vs. stellar mass main sequence as star forming galaxies, whether their star formation process is enhanced by mergers or suppressed by BH activity. We will also determine the galaxy gas content and gas fraction in the quasar phase. Our observations will provide direct constraints on the mode of star formation and feedback during the peak epoch of BH growth, shedding light on the origin of BH/galaxy mass correlation.
